title: Misconceptions about falling objects

multiple-choice.question: What happens when Jack drops two balls of different weights at the same time?

options.label: A
options.text: The heavier ball hits the ground first.

options.label: B
options.text: The lighter ball hits the ground first.

options.label: C
options.text: Both balls hit the ground at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the common misconception about the acceleration of objects falling towards the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: They accelerate at a decreasing rate.

options.label: B
options.text: They fall with a constant speed.

options.label: C
options.text: They accelerate at an increasing rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the force of gravity on objects falling towards the Earth?

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them fall at a constant speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the gravitational force on two objects of different weights?

options.label: A
options.text: The force is greater on the heavier object.

options.label: B
options.text: The force is less on the heavier object.

options.label: C
options.text: The force is the same on both objects.

multiple-choice.question: Why do objects of different weights fall at the same rate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have the same gravitational force acting on them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have different amounts of inertia.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are in a vacuum.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are dropped from the same height.

multiple-choice.question: What is inertia, and how does it relate to an object's acceleration?

options.label: A
options.text: Inertia is an object's resistance to acceleration, and it increases with mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Inertia is an object's tendency to accelerate, and it decreases with mass.

options.label: C
options.text: Inertia is an object's velocity, and it is independent of mass.

options.label: D
options.text: Inertia is an object's weight, and it is proportional to mass.

multiple-choice.question: If you were to drop two objects of different weights on the Moon, what would happen?

options.label: A
options.text: The heavier object would hit the ground first.

options.label: B
options.text: The lighter object would hit the ground first.

options.label: C
options.text: Both objects would hit the ground at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: How does the force of gravity on an object relate to its mass?

options.label: A
options.text: The force of gravity increases with mass.

options.label: B
options.text: The force of gravity decreases with mass.

options.label: C
options.text: The force of gravity is independent of mass.

options.label: D
options.text: The force of gravity is proportional to the square of the mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between an object's weight and its mass?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight is a measure of an object's mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass is a measure of an object's weight.

options.label: C
options.text: Weight is a measure of the force of gravity on an object, while mass is a measure of its resistance to acceleration.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass is a measure of an object's volume, while weight is a measure of its density.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to understand the concept of inertia when studying the motion of objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Because inertia determines an object's velocity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because inertia determines an object's acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: Because inertia affects an object's resistance to changes in its motion.

options.label: D
options.text: Because inertia is irrelevant to an object's motion.

title: The beginning of the universe, for beginners - Tom Whyntie

multiple-choice.question: What field of scientific study is devoted to understanding the universe and its evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive explosion of a star

options.label: C
options.text: The monumental explosion of an infinitely hot, infinitely small point

options.label: D
options.text: The formation of the first atoms

options.label: B
options.text: Using particle accelerators to smash subatomic particles

options.label: C
options.text: Studying the properties of black holes

options.label: D
options.text: Analyzing the light from distant stars

options.label: A
options.text: It allows physicists to see further into the future

options.label: B
options.text: It enables physicists to study the properties of atoms in more detail

options.label: C
options.text: It effectively allows physicists to peek further back in time

options.label: D
options.text: It provides no additional insights into the universe's origins

multiple-choice.question: What was the state of matter in the universe hundreds of seconds after the Big Bang?

options.label: A
options.text: It was composed of fully formed atoms

options.label: B
options.text: It was a swirling sea of subatomic matter

options.label: C
options.text: It was a mixture of atoms and subatomic particles

options.label: D
options.text: It was primarily composed of dark matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of physicists in building more powerful particle accelerators?

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: To see back to a time when all the forces were one and the same

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the behavior of black holes

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model that describes the fundamental building blocks of matter, including quarks?

options.label: A
options.text: The Standard Model of particle physics

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of combining knowledge of the very big (cosmology) with the very small (particle physics)?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a more complete understanding of the universe's origins

options.label: B
options.text: It allows physicists to study the properties of atoms in more detail

options.label: C
options.text: It enables the creation of new, heavier elements

options.label: D
options.text: It provides no additional insights into the universe's origins

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of sharing knowledge and insights between cosmologists and particle physicists?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new field of study that combines cosmology and particle physics

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new technologies for space exploration

options.label: C
options.text: To gain a deeper understanding of the universe and its evolution

options.label: D
options.text: To prove a specific scientific theory

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self-assembly in the context of engineering and biology?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where ordered parts are manually assembled into a structure

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own

options.label: C
options.text: A method of reproduction in living organisms

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of self-assembly in biology?

options.label: B
options.text: The folding of proteins into 3D structures

multiple-choice.question: What forces contribute to the self-assembly of proteins into 3D structures?

options.label: B
options.text: The interaction between amino acids along the chain and the relationship between the chain and the environment

multiple-choice.question: How do viruses self-assemble?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the interaction of amino acids along a chain

options.label: C
options.text: Through the attraction of specific shapes that fit together in precise ways

options.label: D
options.text: By manual assembly of individual components

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential application of self-assembly in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: The construction of buildings that can adapt to environmental changes

options.label: B
options.text: The development of more efficient fossil fuels

options.label: C
options.text: The creation of manual assembly lines

options.label: D
options.text: The design of electronic devices with fixed structures

multiple-choice.question: How can self-assembly be used to build a perfect sphere?

options.label: B
options.text: By inflating like a balloon or creating identical pieces that come together

multiple-choice.question: What is one advantage of using self-assembly in engineering?

options.label: B
options.text: Improved adaptability and reduced human error

multiple-choice.question: How are scientists using self-assembly in the development of molecular microchips?

options.label: B
options.text: By creating small molecular elements that form themselves into organized pathways

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential application of self-assembly in the field of medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of drugs that can only be released through manual injection

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of 3D structures with DNA that can deliver drugs inside the body

options.label: C
options.text: The design of medical devices with fixed structures

options.label: D
options.text: The construction of hospitals that cannot adapt to environmental changes

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential future of factories and construction sites with the use of self-assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: They will become more manual and less adaptive

options.label: B
options.text: They will become more like organisms or brains that grow and adapt independently

options.label: C
options.text: They will remain the same as they are today

options.label: D
options.text: They will become more reliant on fossil fuels
